body: Currently broken due to the state of `develop`.

Hmm, when writing this, for some reason I was convinced that IOException wasn't being handled properly and would cause the test to fail.  Going back and looking closer at the HealthMonitor code, it clearly does get handled properly.  It's not quite the same race as what we're trying to test, but it still get handled correctly and the vast majority of the time we'll test the racing threads.

Adding brackets alone does not fix the problem. I tested this change without adding the double quotes, and it does not fix the issue. It causes the same exception to be thrown by the browser.. "Uncaught ReferenceError: server is not defined" member name is server-1 in this test. Using latest Chrome.
all checks are good. Please review.
Thanks, I'll do that. Any suggestions on where to add such a method?
I was just thinking it would be in this test

@upthewaterspout @mhansonp Ping!!! So this issue has gone unresolved for a week. I'm inclined to side with @upthewaterspout on this one and delete the task altogether until such time (if ever) it provides meaningful value to run them again.

Hello @pivotal-amurmann,
The new commit contains the fix for the failed test and a rebase against {{develop}} because there was a lot of recent conflicts. So yes, the PR is ready for review.
Cheers.

This is a new PR remodeled after all the tests were moved to a new location and hence previous PRs cannot be merged into develop
I am waiting on precheckin  tests to be completed but not on approvals because the previous PR was already approved.
New PR created. After the tests class refactoring this PR cannot be merged. Closing this PR
rebased on develop again

@aditya87 That's a lot of commits. Generally those should either be combined into a single commit or in my personal preference a small, curated set of commits that make it easy to understand what happened. An example for the later case might be: 1. commit that refactors existing code, 2. commit that makes the now easy change.
My guess is that your work is mostly additive and therefore squashing to a single commit might be good. Maybe you have a better idea though how to break this up into digestible commits. Things like "Apply spotless" and "Remove newline" should be squashed by the time a PR happens.
@pivotal-amurmann Sure, I can look into squashing into a more reasonable set of commits.
I'm with @upthewaterspout and @pivotal-jbarrett -- I think we should remove the task, especially for PR pipelines.
Ok, I will work to get that done.
@upthewaterspout @pivotal-jbarrett @galen-pivotal  Deleted the pipeline file, now working with Sean to verify that it gets deleted properly.
Apparently this needs to merged before it will take affect in the PR pipeline.

Hello @pivotal-amurmann!!,
The new `UpgradeTest` CI failures are not related to my changes, from the stack trace looks like an sporadic I/O problem:

```
  Caused by:
        java.io.IOException: No such file or directory
            at java.io.UnixFileSystem.createFileExclusively(Native Method)
            at java.io.File.createTempFile(File.java:2024)
            at org.junit.rules.TemporaryFolder.createTemporaryFolderIn(TemporaryFolder.java:134)
```

Can you fire the pipeline again and merge the changes?.
Best regards.
Looks like some tests are failing, will have to investigate so will close for now

+0.5. I don't mind the messages, but I don't find them to be a very useful indicator of progress, as the test name is only logged after it has finished.

git commit --allow-empty && git push

We have one test failure related to the destroy logic running in its own non-blocking task, and the test not waiting for that logic to complete.  Looking into a fix now.
Tests are running again with a fix for the non-blocking behavior.
Dang github marked this as closed, but it's actually merged to develop.
@mhansonp @balesh2

@upthewaterspout Thanks for the feedback.

When we initialize a TrustManagerFactory with `null`, the default implementation is to load and trust all certs available in the trust store shipped with JDK (for eg: <JDK installed location>/jre/lib/security/cacerts).
Only distributed test failure was flaky. Can I get a quick gradle/IJ love form @upthewaterspout @kirklund. This is a minor gradle update that fixes some parallel javadoc issues.
I checked out the branch to do some building and IntelliJ testing.

The new approach is to delete the test. The two lock grantors can be on different servers and aren't guaranteed to recover in any sort of sync. The change for https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/GEODE-4928 reduces, but doesn't fix, this issue. I think it's a new feature we could add, not a bug, but probably not the highest priority for now. See the discussion in GEODE-4928 for more.
rebased on develop.
Thanks @zdre I'll retest in chrome.

I think it might be better if the parameter were more specific - something like `ssl-key-management-provider` or `ssl-use-default-key-management`. I'd also prefer not adding specific options for trust-manager and key-manager but just have a single option seeing that they will always go together.
failure due to an existing issue, not related to this PR.
@upthewaterspout info is a non-default flag that would need to be set to get the output
@rhoughton-pivot Since this was only caught by doing `install` let's add `install` to the CI pipeline. Perhaps as part of the `Build` job.

@jdeppe-pivotal this PR is ready if you want to give it your blessing.
LGTM - seems to be fine both in IntelliJ and from the command line.

@galen-pivotal - This test is in a base class that is extended by a whole bunch of other tests that configure different region types - so this is run with either ack or no-ack.

The test has seen failures for some time, but it may be worse now with the newer infrastructure.
PR failure not related to this PR
@pivotal-jbarrett @rhoughton-pivot @metatype

@pivotal-jbarrett 
Looks like we have default values used when not specified by the user.  Specifically for `ssl-keystore defaults to {user.home}/.keystore` and `ssl-truststore defaults to {user.home}/.truststore`. So making `default context` as the normal use-case would break backward compatibility.

legacy test-run & test-archive scripts are still used for windows jobs and are copied to `scripts/windows`. We still have work to speed up jobs on windows and refactoring windows jobs to the newer scripts can be taken with speedup activity and merging this sooner helps to avoid breakages caused by changes to code on develop.

I like Darrel's idea of setting detectReadConflicts per transaction. I think It is much simpler for user to do it this way.
However, this could only be set in commit(boolean detectReadConflicts) not in begin() method, as we do not send message when transaction begin.

Please note use this approach, you may need to handle message sending between two different version servers (geode supports rolling upgrade).
@metatype can you resolve this conflicts and resubmit. It would be nice to get these deps updated.

Please update the LICENSE file (https://github.com/apache/geode/blob/develop/geode-assembly/src/main/dist/LICENSE) with an entry for classgraph under the MIT section (we should have added an entry for fast-classpath-scanner but missed it).
Working on it.  There's a conflict where cargo and cglib pull in differing versions of ant (really!) causing test failures.

FYI, I have an experimental pipeline running that is looking for new tests and running them 50 times in a row. For this PR, it looks like one of the tests failed 3/50 times. Maybe this test has some timing issues?

Tests in progress

Developers should also note that, due to gradle task-name abbreviation, this target can be reached via `./gradlew dev` or `./gradlew dB`.

As a side note: `./gradlew d` abbreviates an ambiguous target.  Note also, `./gradlew de` is **not** ambiguous and will target `./gradlew dependencies`, since the gradle matcher prefers full-word-case-matching.

@smgoller @mhansonp
@kirklund GitHub UI calls them renames but they are really moves. All those files get moved to new homes but otherwise remain unchanged.

Worked for me as well. I initially ran into some `cannot find symbol` errors in IntelliJ 2018.2, but those got resolved once I followed your recommendations on the dev list last month to disable  "Create separate module per source set" and enable auto import.  I updated the wiki page to reflect these new setup requirements. Thoughts on adding this to the readme as well?
